comment.body: Please also see https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1037#issuecomment-869091204: Does removing old BIKE versions indeed mean BIKE's not supported on 32bitters any more? Or was BIKE never meant to run on such chips?

issue.title: Pull updated NTRU Prime from PQClean

comment.body: When trying to resolve this issue, `copy_from_upstream.py` failed to function correctly, as it has an (apparently) incorrect constant baked in [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/d9fb4e0e81ccd0a0972b38743404d982fe0a90c1/scripts/copy_from_upstream/src/kem/kem.h/algs_length.fragment#L3): This "27" seems to stem from the non-PQClean-originating algorithms and apparently now is wrong (probably since #1013). @bhess: Do you agree? @xvzcf @dstebila : Do you have suggestions how to resolve this? Should we somewhere have a counter of non-PQClean algs that breaks when the algorithm count changes? Or shall we simply manually adapt it at each import run? The currently correct number seems to be "29"... But that's not really robust...

issue.title: Pull updated NTRU Prime from PQClean

comment.body:
> This "27" seems to stem from the non-PQClean-originating algorithms and apparently now is wrong (probably since #1013)

Yes, it's the number of algorithms not pulled automatically by copy_from_upstream (pqclean and pqcrystals). Perhaps it's better to keep track of this number outside the copy_from_upstream templates.

issue.title: checking NIST levels in generate.py
issue.body:
Fixes #315 

This new logic could also be used to completely do away with fields "[bits_]security" in `generate.yml` (as it can deduce them from `liboqs`' `claimed_nist_level`. What'd you think @dstebila @xvzcf ?

comment.body:
> Compiling code looked more simple to me than exposing the NIST levels to downstream code by other means. Whatever, then do you suggest not dealing with #315? Or do you suggest another approach?

My first thought was that downstream projects could use the coming-soon™ YAML documentation sheets in liboqs, but I haven't thought it through. What do you think?

issue.title: checking NIST levels in generate.py
issue.body:
Fixes #315 

This new logic could also be used to completely do away with fields "[bits_]security" in `generate.yml` (as it can deduce them from `liboqs`' `claimed_nist_level`. What'd you think @dstebila @xvzcf ?

comment.body:
> My first thought was that downstream projects could use the coming-soon™ YAML documentation sheets in liboqs, but I haven't thought it through. What do you think?

Good for me _if_ those YAML files are "the source of truth" (for `liboqs` code/constants, incl. test suite): If that were given, I'd be fine reading them in for doing NIST-level dependent "stuff" in downstream projects: Main thing is that `liboqs` internal NIST-level logic (or even code) shall not be different from what the downstreams "think"/know about them.

issue.title: Pull updated NTRU Prime from PQClean

comment.body:
> Perhaps it's better to keep track of this number outside the copy_from_upstream templates.

Fully agree. @xvzcf Mirroring your thought on the NIST levels, could we maybe pull that number (of non-PQClean algs) from the coming-soon™ YML docs, too?

issue.title: Support for x86 and ppc64le architectures
issue.body:
As requested in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1019#issuecomment-868131725
Two commits to support builds on x86 (`i686`) and ppc64le, all algorithms are supposed to build as generic implementations.

Tested and all tests are passing on [ALT Linux](http://git.altlinux.org/people/vt/packages/?p=liboqs.git;a=shortlog;h=refs/tags/0.6.0-alt2). Our build logs (with tests run):
* http://git.altlinux.org/tasks/archive/done/_269/275542/build/100/i586/log
* http://git.altlinux.org/tasks/archive/done/_269/275542/build/100/ppc64le/log

ps. These two commits are just `cherry-pick`'ed from our downstream repo, with some conflict resolved for the second one.

comment.body: Code looks good to me for now. But I'd like to get at least an x86 CI build before merging.

issue.title: Support for x86 and ppc64le architectures
issue.body:
As requested in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1019#issuecomment-868131725
Two commits to support builds on x86 (`i686`) and ppc64le, all algorithms are supposed to build as generic implementations.

Tested and all tests are passing on [ALT Linux](http://git.altlinux.org/people/vt/packages/?p=liboqs.git;a=shortlog;h=refs/tags/0.6.0-alt2). Our build logs (with tests run):
* http://git.altlinux.org/tasks/archive/done/_269/275542/build/100/i586/log
* http://git.altlinux.org/tasks/archive/done/_269/275542/build/100/ppc64le/log

ps. These two commits are just `cherry-pick`'ed from our downstream repo, with some conflict resolved for the second one.

comment.body:
Thanks @vt-alt for preparing this.

I've set up simplistic TravisCI config for ppc64le on top of the PR to build and run the ninja tests (still running the constant-time tests on another machine). See
https://github.com/bhess/liboqs/tree/travis-ppc
https://travis-ci.com/github/bhess/liboqs

We can add the TravisCI build if we want to make exception and slightly expand the CI zoo again. The plus points are that it's free for ppc64le (and s390x). For more advanced workflow like triggering downstream builds it could become more complex however. I think if we limit to build&test it should be manageable.

It might also make sense to push the SIKE changes to upstream.

issue.title: Pull updated NTRU Prime from PQClean

comment.body:
> Fully agree. @xvzcf Mirroring your thought on the NIST levels, could we maybe pull that number (of non-PQClean algs) from the coming-soon™ YML docs, too?

Yes I think that might be a better place since we should have a full view of all the liboqs algorithms there.
